required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mid-morning Gel Snacks on Subjective Appetite, Glycemic and Insulin Responses, and Food Intake
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Mid-Morning Gel Snacks on Subjective Appetite, Glycemic and Insulin Responses, and Food Intake in Healthy Adults

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of mid-morning gel snacks on subjective appetite, glucose and insulin responses, and food intake in healthy weight young adults.

detailed_description.textblock: 23 (14 male, 9 female) healthy, non-smoking human subjects aged 18-30 years with a body mass index (BMI) between 20 and 24.9 were recruited in the experiment. Five gel snacks including a control snack and four modified snacks containing whey protein, oats, coconut oil or maltodextrin were tested. On six separate mornings, at least 3 days apart and after a 12 hours overnight fast, each participant consumed a standardized breakfast of cereal, milk, and orange juice at home, then arrived in the lab 2 hours after breakfast to receive one of the five test snack treatments or skip snack. Subjective appetite by a 100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS) was measured at baseline (0 min) and after each treatment up to 2 h (15, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min). Blood glucose and insulin concentrations were measured via finger-prick at the same time VAS measurements were taken. Food intake was measured via ad libitum pizza lunch.

study_design_info.masking_description: Coded snacks in shaded tetrapaks were provided to participants

primary_outcome.description: Participants completed subjective ratings on appetite (e.g., desire to eat, hunger, fullness, prospective food consumption) and well-being at baseline (0 min), 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, and 120 min after snack consumption, as well as immediately following lunch.

secondary_outcome.description: Blood was collected at baseline (0min), 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, and 120 min after snack consumption, as well as immediately following lunch to observe glycemic responses to gel snacks
Blood was collected at baseline (0 min), 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, and 120 min after meal consumption, as well as immediately following lunch, to observe insulin responses to gel snacks
Participants consumed an ad libitum pizza lunch at 120 minutes

arm_group.description: Participants received control snacks prepared by real fruits (pear, orange and mango)
Participants received maltodextrin snacks (maltodextrin + control snack)
Participants received whey protein snacks (whey protein + control snack)
Participants received oat snacks (oat + maltodextrin + control snack)
Participants received coconut oil snacks (coconut oil + control snack)

intervention.description: Isovolumetric (238.4g) gel snack prepared by real fruits (186.2kcal)
Isovolumetric (238.4g) gel snack with whey protein (201.8kcal)
Isovolumetric (238.4g) gel snack with oats and maltodextrin (275.8kcal)
Isovolumetric (238.4g) gel snack with coconut oil (276.4kcal)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- be between 18 and 30 years of age
- be healthy, non-smoking and not be taking any medications, including birth control
- body mass index (BMI) between 20 and 24.9
Exclusion Criteria:
- fasting plasma glucose >5.5 mmol/L
- health problems including previously diagnosed diabetes, known or uncertain pregnancy status at screening, gastrointestinal disease, liver or kidney disease
- major medical or surgical event within the past 6 months
- current or recent dieting
- breakfast skipping
- receiving any medications
- menstrual irregularities
- food sensitivities, allergies, intolerances, or dietary restrictions to foods including: cereal, orange juice, dairy, oat, coconut oil, honey, apple, pineapple, strawberry, and pear
- behavioural or emotional problems
- alcohol consumption >7 beverages/week
